title: romero121
author: romero121
content: Guys down to the official tweet from Vitalik about the release of his Book Proof Of Stake there is a scam account that resembles same as Vitalik's official Twitter account. If you watch closely you can easily find the difference. The scammer have described about a 100,000 ETH as a celebration of merge. Please be careful and don't loss your ethereum.

comments.author: Kemarit
comments.body: Thanks, I haven't check this one out yet but we all know that this scammers are going to used this one. And it just make sense of this criminals to take advantage because ETH and Vitalik is on the social media and other news because of the ETH Merge.And hopefully no gullible crypto enthusiast will fall for this. We've seen a lot of fake giveaways from Elon Musk during his height as a so called crypto influencer to Vitalik today.

comments.author: Jawhead999
comments.body: I don't know if it's a bot or real users, but they're replying the scammer tweet like it's genuine lol. Actually it's already clear the difference is from their twitter username, smart people wouldn't get trapped by this particular scam.I search @rolmeda real name is Rafael Olmeda, who is him? if his account doesn't get hacked, I think he will go to the jail if there's many report created and the police obviously can get his personal information considering social media have low privacy.

comments.author: $crypto$
comments.body: I think this is a common thing where many verified Twitter accounts are hacked and turned into vitalik.buterin accounts to create fake giveaways with 100,000 ETH to be distributed, this is very illogical and how can there be a giveaway of that size, but somehow scammers have to stay alert for any scams, whereas verified accounts usually have a lot of followers so the target of scammers is their followers who don't know anything and try to do it, that's what we need to realize that it's all a scam.There is one thread from @ajiz138 about scams with verified Twitter. Fake Giveaway Ethereum: by using the blue tick (verification) on his Twitter

comments.body: Blue tag is really a mess especially the one who handle it is a professional scammer. Also I cant be fool with such followers like that. Vitalik has million followers and this one is not. Better to restrict accounts caught imitating or copying others.

comments.author: el kaka22
comments.body: I am sorry but this is such an easy thing to see that if you are still falling for it, maybe you need to fall for it to learn better? At the end of the day I have never got fooled by these before, but let's assume I could back in the day when they first started, but now?Now, we are talking about something that is insanely common and people are still falling for it, this is known now and it is common enough that even newbies know about it, and you still feel like it could be real? In that case you should be staying away from it. Back in the day, they would even get names close to Vitalik as well, nowadays their username is totally different at least.

comments.author: Flexystar
comments.body: Oh yeah this scam, nothing new. In fact I’m so used to it that if someday Real vitalik publishes such giveaway then also I won’t believe it.   It’s like I have switched on ignore butting for 100,000 ETH on the Twitter. There is no point in believing in such stuff and I am sadden if anyone or even a noob is falling for such trap. First thing first, this is internet world where nobody sees no one and it’s literally net of trap! If there is any positive news, like even if some celebrity is giving birth then these scammers will turn that news into profit making machine. By the time scams are exposed many people get scammed. Better self learn and keep teaching others to stay away from these.

comments.author: abel1337
comments.body: I was honestly baited on the photo on my first glance, I just noticed the username because of the red box. Scammers are improving nowadays and they seem using blue check accounts to imitate others. This is like an upgraded version of the twitter Elon Musk copycat scams that are doing the same thing which is giveaways. I'm not fond of joining these kind of too good to be true offers in social media but I'm sure someone can possibly fall in the scammers hand by just having these blue checks on their username.

comments.author: Jackl87
comments.body: Quote from: romero121 on September 28, 2022, 08:12:24 AMGuys down to the official tweet from Vitalik about the release of his Book Proof Of Stake there is a scam account that resembles same as Vitalik's official Twitter account. If you watch closely you can easily find the difference. The scammer have described about a 100,000 ETH as a celebration of merge. Please be careful and don't loss your ethereum.Well thanks for the warning OP. I think though that this warning is mostly relevant for people that are pretty new to the crypto space, because everyone else that has at least a few weeks of experience in this space knows already that the crypto world is full of scammers and shillers. You always need to check the account name on twitter as you have outlined and this is not only true for twitter but also for telegram. People can choose the display name that they like and there can be thousands of the same nickname at the same time, but your account name has to be unique. Always be careful guys and never give away your private key to anyone and never connect your wallet to a linked website.

comments.author: isaac_clarke22
comments.body: I see this a lot while treading in Twitter. It also happens in Facebook wherein an official news article page would post then a fake clone of the page would comment out. If the page would do giveaways anyways, they could just do it in another post. When I see a supposed official page comment out on their own post, I sometimes get a lot suspicious from it and I never click any sort of links from the comment for obvious purposes let alone if Telegram link was given, lol.

comments.author: rugrats
comments.body: The best thing is to always be skeptical about all giveaway events, always check them all on social media before joining, don't be too hasty for fear of missing out. Scammers always take advantage of the big events of some famous coins to scam. The people who often fall into the trap are mostly newbies because they lack the knowledge to distinguish what is a scam from what is real.
